p.seg: [In the past when Rong Cheng,
Zun Lu, He Xu,
Gao Xin, Cang Jie,
Xuanyuan, Shengnong,
Hun Dun and Fu Xi possessed all under Heaven,
in each occasion they did not give (it) to their sons,
but gave (it) to worthy people,
their virtue was deep and clear,
and those above cared for those below,
and they unified their intent,
and stopped the troops,
and employed offcials according to their natural qualities.
Thereupon the deaf mutes would hold torches,
the ones with troubled eyesight and the blind would play the lute,
the ones stumbling and the lame would guard the doors,
the midgets would be in charge of (making) arrows,
the (abnormally) tall would divine about locations,
the hunchbacks would do calculations,
the ones with goitrie would cook in the salines,
the bald would fish in the marshes,
the sick and the abandoned would not [...]
In general as for those between the people who were of low status,
he would teach them and instruct them,
give them to drink and to eat,
have them serving the hundred officials
and instruct them monthly.
Therefore in that period,
there would not be anxiety [...]
[when ...] possessed the empire,
he would concentrate on caring (=for the people)
and disregard tax collection,
making a personal effort at toiling for the people.
[...] therefore he did not give rewards not fines,
he did not administer punishments nor death penalties,
so that in the country there were no starving men
and on the road there was nobody who died before his time.
Those above and those below, nobles and people of low status,
each had its own place.
Those outside the four seas would submit,
those inside would rectify themselves,
even birds and beasts would come to court,
even fish and turtles would present tributes,
those who have and those who have not would be in relationship (with each other).
He rectified the government of all under Heaven for nineteen years
and ruled as a king over all under Heaven for thirty seven years
until he passed away (?).
In the past Yao lived between Danfu and Diling.
Yao enacted his (agricultural) policies (?) and often thanked (the spirits),
he did not push them and yet the people would toil to their outmost,
he did not apply punishments and capital penalties and yet there were no bandits,
he was extremely indulgent and yet the people submitted (to him).
Thereupon within a (radius) of a hundred square miles,
those leading the population all under Heaven
came to pay respect and established him
to serve as emperor.
Thereupon from a thousand square miles
they brought their tablets and rectified their positions,
from the four directions they entrusted and harmonized themselves (with him),
through (his) love he summoned the people all under Heaven.
His government was orderly and he did not give rewards,
he appointed officials and did not give fiefs,
he did not urge the people
and they were orderly and not exhausted.
Therefore it is said:
“Worthy men come [...].
By means of these (criteria) one sees (=evaluates) a worthy man:
he treads the Earth and has Heaven above his head (=he behaves as a model),
he is earnest in his righteousness and trust,
he brings unity (to people) between Heaven and Earth
and embraces (everything) within the four seas
- if he can use his abilities to the utmost in his occupations,
then he can be established as Son of Heaven.
Yao instructed them:
“If you let him in,
I will pry on him through a hole.”
It was done to obtain a worthy man
and to abdicate to a worthy man.
Yao (wanted to) abdicate all under Heaven to a worthy man,
but among worthy man under Heaven
none could receive it.
the rulers of the myriad states
all (wanted to) abdicate their states to worthy men,
[...] worthy men,
but no worthy men could receive them.
Therefore the people all under Heaven
reputed Yao to be good in elevating a worthy man,
and finally establish him (as emperor).
In the past, Shun was tilling the soil at Li Hills,
he was making pottery on the banks of the [Yellow] River,
and fishing in the Lei marshes.
He filially nourished his parents
and was good to his relatives
and thereby reached all the sons of his country (=his fellow countrymen).
Yao heard about it
and praised his behavior.
Thus Yao had fifteen chariots arranged,
to visit Shun thrice amidst the fields.
Upon this, Shun started by avoiding holding (=setting aside) the hoe (?) and the ploughshare,
and let him sit separated (=they sat in front of each other).
Master Yao faced south;
Shun faced north.
Shun then started talking to Yao
about the Way of the people, and of Heaven-and-Earth.
He spoke to him about governmental affairs,
encouraging him to behave simply;
he spoke to him about music
encouraging him to ensure harmony in order to prolong (his reign?).
He spoke to him about ritual,
encouraging him to be broad (=all encompassing, tolerant) in order not to face opposition.
Yao then was glad.
Yao [then became aged,
his sight was no longer clear],
his hearing no longer sharp.
Yao had nine sons;
but he did not make his son heir.
He observed Shun’s worthiness
and wanted to make him his heir.
[Shun then yielded five times to the worthy people of all under Heaven,
but there was nothing to do about it,
and only after that he dared to accept it (=the throne)].
Shun had the government for three years,
and as mountains and hills were not dredged,
so that accumulated water could not flow,
then he appointed Yu as Master of Works.
After Yu accepted the appointment,
he dressed in straw clothes and put on a bamboo (?) hat,
(the skin on his) face was dry and coarse,
on his legs would not grow any hair (?),
he opened up blocked (channels) and made (the waters) flow.
(Then) Yu personally held a straw basket for carrying earth and a spade to dig,
to build embankments for the Ming Du (=Meng Zhu) marshes,
he removed the obstructions of the seven rivers,
thereupon the Jia and Xu provinces could start being inhabited.
Yu then opened communications between the Huai and the Yi rivers,
diverting them into the sea in the East,
thereupon the Qing and Lü provinces could start being inhabited.
Yu then opened communications between the Lou and the Tang rivers,
diverting them into the sea in the East,
thereupon the You province could start being inhabited.
Yu then opened communications between the three rivers and the five lakes,
diverting them into the sea in the East, thereupon the Jing and Yang provinces could start being inhabited.
Yu then opened communications between the rivers Yi, Luo, Bing, Chang and Jian,
diverting them into the sea in the East,
thereupon the Yu province could start being inhabited.
Yu then opened communications between the rivers Jing and Wei,
diverting them into the sea in the North,
thereupon the Yong province could start being inhabited.
Then Yu named five hundred valleys at the south of the Han river,
and five hundred at the north.
The dwellings of the people all under Heaven became stable,
then they plowed to feed themselves,
then he appointed Hou Ji as their inspector of fields.
After Hou Ji had accepted his appointment
he ate in the open fields,
he slept in the open fields,
he improved the (varieties of) grains and enriched the soil,
so that after five years there were abundant harvests.
The people had food surplus,
and there was nothing they couldn’t ask for and get,
therefore the people thanked the gods.
(But) an attitude of arrogance started to rise.
Then he appointed Gao Tao as judicial official.
After Gao Tao had accepted his appointment,
then he differentiated the Ying and the Yang pneuma (propitious and unpropitious occasions)
and attended the litigations,
and after three years there was none among the people all under Heaven who had litigations.
All under Heaven there was great harmony and equality,
Yu then wanted to collect the pneuma of Heaven and earth (?)
and attend to it and employ it,
then he appointed Zhi as music master.
After Zhi had accepted his appointment, he made the six pitch pipes X and the six pitch pipes Y,
to differentiate the five tones
and to establish the sounds of the voices of men and women.
At that time
no epidemics came,
no evil portents enacted (themselves).
Disasters and calamities were eradicated and disappeared,
beasts and birds were fat and big,
grass and trees grew tall.
The way in which in the past Heaven and-Earth supported Shun
and assisted the good,
was just of this shape.
Then Shun became aged,
his sight was no longer clear,
his ears no longer sharp.
Shun had seven sons;
but he did not make his son heir.
He observed Yu’s worthiness
and wanted to make him his heir.
Yu then yielded five times to the worthiest All under Heaven,
but had no choice,
and finally dared to receive it [the throne].
Yu had the government for three years,
he did not make leather (=armors),
he did not mold metal into blades,
nor did he sharpen arrows,
in the fields there were no wild grasses,
houses were not empty,
and frontier gates and market places had no taxes.
Then Yu relied on those (lands) in the mountains and hills that were level and humid that could be enfeoffed as cities
and made them florishing and filled (with people);
then he relied on what is close to know what is far,
he eliminated what is too severe and complicated and enacted what is simple,
following the wishes of the people,
uniting what is advantageous in Heaven and earth,
and by means of this those who were close rejoiced in the order (of his government),
and those who were far spontaneously came.
Those within the four seas came,
those outside invariably asked to present tribute.
Yu then started to make signals and banners for them,
to establish a difference between their left and right,
doing so that the people would not be led into confusion.
He used the sun for the banner of the eastern direction,
the moon for the western one,
the snake for the southern one,
the bear for the central and proper banner,
the bird for the northern one.
Then Yu started to act with frugality:
the clothes would not be colored and beautiful,
the food would have no strong taste,
those coming to court audience would not be met with a carriage,
in hulling (grain) one would not (reduce it to) fine grains,
in butchering (meat) one would not break the bones.
There would be three announcements in every direction,
and these would be the rules for sounds requesting help:
in the eastern direction there would be three announcements,
three in the west,
three in the south,
three in the north,
to protect the river valleys
and to cross the large rivers,
to ascend high mountains
and enter thick forests,
and thereby to enact the government (?).
Thereupon he started to give fiefs and provide salary,
to yield to those (worthy men) coming,
so thriving, so all embracing,
Yu then placed a drum in front of the court,
made for those of the people that had complaints to drum upon.
When the drum was beaten,
Yu would always come out quickly,
not daring to give up because of the cold in winter,
nor because of the heat in summer.
He personally talked [??]
[...] deep place.
He said:
the sage,
when (men) are alive he provides nourishment (for them),
when (they) are dead he provides burial (for them),
he eliminates what is severe and wrong,
thereby establishing his reputation.
Yu had five sons,
but he did not make (one of) his sons heir.
He observed Gao Yao’s worthiness
and wanted to make him his heir.
Gao Yao then yielded five times to the worthiest in All under Heaven,
and afterwards pled ill,
did not leave [his house], and died.
Yu then yielded to Yi,
but then [Yu’s son] Qi attacked Yi and seized power for himself.
[His heirs] ruled All under Heaven for sixteen years [should be: generations],
and Jie appeared.
Jie did not follow the road of the earlier kings,
made [changes] by himself [...]
[...] in that time,
(lords from) both strong and weak (states) would not refuse to listen (to unfounded accusations),
(lords from) both densely populated and scarcely populated (states) would not attend litigations (=lawsuits),
the affairs of Heaven and earth and the four season would not be attended.
Tang [should be: Jie] then greatly enacted levies and taxes,
and levied taxes on frontier posts and markets.
It is then no surprise that the people would be resentful,
violent illnesses started to arise,
thereupon there was the beginning of the rise of deaf and mute people, people stumbling, people blind from one eye, people with a goitrie, hunchbacks, bald people.
Tang then made plans and followed strict rules to attract worthy people,
and then appointed Yi Yin as his helper.
After Yi Yin had accepted his appointment,
then he held weapons and stopped violence.
He feigned having obtained (trust) from the people (of Xia),
and therefore (Jie) went astray
and did not evaluate the insufficiency of his strength,
he raised the army to attack Min Shan
and took his two daughters Yan and Wan,
then moved north leaving his state (?),
building the Qing palace,
the precious jade Hall,
decorating the beautiful jade tower,
erecting the jade gate.
His arrogance and extravagance had this appearance.
Tang heard about it,
thereupon he was careful and observed strict rules in seeking worthy people,
he was virtuous and kind and not too self reliant (=self conceited),
he accumulated (good actions) for thirty years
and then was able to obtain it (=good governance).
As even (acting like this) he could not (change Jie),
after that he proceeded to attack him.
Tang ascended through the Er channel,
entered through the northern gate,
set his camp at central [.].
Jie then ecaped to Li mountain.
Tang again followed and attacked him,
he descended through the Ming Tiao channel,
to attack the gate of the High spirits.
Jie then escaped to Nan Chao.
Tang again followed and attacked him,
then he fled
leaving for the open fields of Cang Wu.
Tang thereupon summoned the armies of the nine provinces,
to descend (on the land) within the four seas,
thereupon the armies of all under Heaven rose greatly,
thereupon they extinguished his kin,
exterminated his clan,
destroyed his people,
and then he submitted. ????
[...] robbers and bandits,
by these means one gets (the approval of) the masses
and reigns over all under Heaven.
Tang (and his descendants)reigned over all under Heaven for thirty one generations
until Zhou rose.
Zhou did not follow the way of the erlier kings,
he instituted changes on his own,
thereupon he built a tower with nine floors.
He put a bowl with charcoal at the bottom,
adding a ring of wood at the top,
having people to tread upon it,
the ones that could advance through it did it,
the ones that could not advance through it
would (be forced to) enter and die.
The ones disobeying his orders would be put in shackles.
Thereupon he made three thousand metal foot fetters.
After having made the metal foot fetters,
he also made a pool of wine,
and would take great pleasure in the wine.
He would therefore be debauched all evening and night,
without attending the government of his state.
Therefore the nine states revolted against him:
Feng, Gao, Zhou, Yu, Lu, Li, Chong, Mi Xu.
King Wen heard about it,
and said:
“Even if the king has lost the way,
would I dare not to serve him?
Even if the father has lost his way,
would the son dare not to serve him?
How could the son of Heaven be rebelled against?”
Zhou heard about it,
and let King Wen come out of the Xia tower (=where he was imprisoned)
and asked him
saying:
“the nine states, can they be caused to come (back to me)?”
King Wen said:
“Yes.”
Thereupon King Wen wore a square suit of white (silk) and a (?) lower garment (=a dress of mourning)
to deal with the nine states,
and seven states came to submit,
(only) Feng and Gao did not submit.
King Wen then raised an army against Feng and Gao
and beat the drum three times
and then let them (=his soldiers) advance (against the two rebel states),
(then) beat the drum three times
and let them (=his soldiers) retreat,
saying:
“What I know is so sad,
if the ruler has lost the way,
which guilt is (to be imputed) to the common people?”
The people of Feng and Gao heard about it,
and then surrendered to King Wen.
King Wen relied on the old calendar
to instruct people about the (right) time (for agricultural works),
letting them to know fully about high and low lying lands and fertile and barren soils,
letting them know the way of Heaven
and the benefits of the Earth,
causing people not to suffer hardships.
(The way in which) in the past King Wen helped Zhou
was like this.
When King Wen passed away,
King Wu ascended the throne.
King Wu said:
“To make virtue perfect,
I will replace him by persuading him.
As second option,
I will replace him by attacking him.
Now Zhou acts without principles,
he confuses and neglects the hundred surnames,
he fetters and binds the feudal lords,
Heaven will punish him.
I will help Heaven to exercize its authority over him.”
King Wu thereupon prepared one thousand war chariots
and ten thousand armored men,
and the 55th day of the cicle
he crossed the Meng ford,
reached (the area) between Gong and Teng,
to have a small (night?) meeting with the armies of the feudal lords in the open fields of Mu.
